"The biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it's taking place. It's the illusion of blame being put on us for a lack of effective communication on which we base our guilt, and which we are complicit in because we refuse to acknowledge the inherent dishonesty and separation from other human beings we experience as an 'untrue' (misleading) picture of unreliable, separating, and separable communicative actions."

"The greatest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place. We are all guilty of projecting our own perceived deficiencies onto others through an unjustified guilt and separation from them."

This phrase, popularized by the author's book "Communication: The Hardest Thing to Do," describes how communication is inherently flawed and interdependent. While individuals are generally unaware of their own communication traps and biases, they can be seen as contributing to the illusion that communication is taking place between them and others. This is because our perceptions and beliefs about ourselves or others shape the way we communicate, making us more likely to assume other people's intentions and motives even when no evidence supports it. In this light, blaming someone for a lack of effective communication or being complicit in its underlying disconnections from perceived guilt and separability is simply ignoring the illusion that communication has taken place.

"the single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place." This phrase, popularized by author Elizabeth L. Cline's book "Communication: The Hardest Thing to Do," is a direct critique of how individuals can project their own perceived deficiencies onto others through an unjustified guilt and separation from them.

Cline's argument is that communication is inherently flawed due to the interdependent nature of communication, as it's impossible to separate the individual from the underlying perceptions and beliefs they bring to the situation. For instance, a person who believes their lack of communication skills is preventing them from receiving valid feedback or praise may then become paranoid about other people's intentions, leading to self-justification and negative assumptions.

Furthermore, Cline argues that when individuals fail to recognize the underlying interdependence of communication, they are not just ignoring the illusion but also perpetuating it by accepting their perceived guilt for not communicating effectively or simply being "complicit" in its underlying misconceptions.

Overall, Cline's insight is that the biggest problem in communication isn't just one individual's flawed perceptions, but rather the interdependent nature of communication and how we all contribute to it through our assumptions and beliefs. By recognizing this, individuals can better engage in honest and open communication with others and overcome the illusion that communication has taken place, leading to more constructive and positive interactions.

Esto es la principal cuestión de comunicación. El lenguaje escrito se presenta como esperado y la escritura en general está relacionada con las líneas escritas y otros elementos del texto que están hechos por alguien (el autor). Tampoco todas las naciones escriben igual, sino que cada uno hace su propio estilo y escribe sobre otro tema. Estos cambios no se consideran como algo único, bien como "otro lenguaje" o bien "un solo lenguaje". 

El principio es el mismo para todas las naciones en su escritura y pronunciación del lenguaje, ya que todo mundo está trabajando con la misma herencia lingüística. No existen más que los cambios de estilo y texto para diferenciar alguien de alguien, como si hubieran estado pensando en un único concepto durante varios años antes de terminar de escribir el texto escrito.

En este artículo, el autor reseña una afirmación de Thomas Kuhn ("El principal problema de la comunicación es que no se trata de la existencia de las ideas", en "The structure of science: The case for the standard model", 1976), una de las principales conclusiones derivadas del trabajo de Kuhn sobre la naturaleza y funciona de los caminos neuronales y los métodos científicos. El artículo se centra en la lógica y el lenguaje, que es inseparable de la realidad.

El autor escribe que las primeras personas que intentaron describir las formas de la escritura escrita en piedra eran esos mismos escritos, ya que apreciaban que todo el mundo trabajaba con la misma herramienta lingüística. Por lo tanto, cualquier cambio del estilo de escritura significaría un nuevo lenguaje, y no existía ningún lenguaje único para describir el mundo.

Agregando más contexto al tema:

En inglés, el principio es que la estructura literaria o la estructura temática de un texto cambian al mismo tiempo que sus ideas. El texto cambia y las ideas cambian en un proceso inseparable. De hecho, esto es exactamente lo que se da cuando un autor publica su trabajo: cambiar el estilo de su escritura mientras escribe. En otras palabras, el estilo del escritor puede no seguir al cambio del libro; su trabajo nunca debe descuidarse ni su estilo sea incompatible con su contenido, ya que la crítica de ese tipo puede llegar a la misma conclusión. A diferencia de este punto de vista, las críticas sobre la naturaleza de las ideas, en lugar de seguir el mismo proceso en una estructura establecido, generalmente suelen intentar demostrar que una idea es incorrecta o insuficiente con respecto a un concepto anterior. 

Estos cambios se identifican en la literatura de todos los países y las edades. La diferencia entre el Reino Unido y la Estados Unidos puede ser que en el Reino Unido, la estructura temática puede variar al mismo tiempo que las ideas, pero el estilo no es un proceso inseparable de la escritura. En el Reino Unido, el cambio de estilo y texto puede ser un proceso independiente, así como las ideas. En Estados Unidos, es el estilo único de la escritura que se considera parte del lenguaje.

Se trata de una estructura neuronal compleja en los sistemas de la humanidad, así que no existe un sistema único, sino una estructura neuronal compleja con varios caminos y métodos para descubrir las ideas. Aunque sea más sencillo que esta teoría, este proceso ha demostrado su valididad durante mucho tiempo a lo largo del mundo, especialmente en la década de 1950. Es el lenguaje común como parte integrante del sistema neuronal, lo que significa que la estructura neuronal compleja no puede ser descubierta sino más bien, se debe a una interpretación individual, a un método o cualquier otro proceso no único del sistema neuronal.

El principal problema en el proceso de comunicación es el illusion del esquema (origen). El esquema ofrece una metodología compleja y estructuración generalizadas para la comunicación, pero no existen un único método para descubrir los pensamientos individuales. El proceso se describe como una estructura neuronal compleja con varias caminos y métodos que pueden explicar y desacelerar la transmisión de ideas. Es una lógica que depende del esquema natural como parte integral del sistema neuronal, lo que significa que no puede ser descubierta sino más bien se debe a una interpretación individual, un método o cualquier otro proceso no único del sistema neuronal.

"The biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place." This quote comes from "Illusions of Transmission" by Friedrich Nietzsche, and it emphasizes the need to be cautious when sharing information as it may not have been genuinely communicated. As for what the single biggest problem in communication is, it suggests that there is often an illusion or misinterpretation of what has actually taken place.

In the given text material, "Przerażając" is a colloquial word for "sneaking." In this context, it means to steal, and to say that something is stolen or sneakily obtained implies that there may be deception or trickery involved. The phrase "Pierwszik, który wykorzystuję jako przykład," translated as the first "assistant" in parentheses, means "the first one who was mentioned in connection with a particular example." The last sentence in the material describes how students attempt to address these perceived issues by changing the language used in the interviews to make them more suitable for understanding of the tax's intended outcome.

Detailed explanation:
The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place. It also means that if you say something that does not really express any of the reasons for what you said, then there are lots of reasons and explanations to explain it! The second most important thing in communication is the belief that somehow saying a lot of logical explanations for non-existent reasons is actually saying more.

The primary cause of this illusion stems from the fact that any explanation given for anything is always suspect. As such, if we say something about what happened, and it does not express any underlying reasons or explanations, then you could misinterpret us in any way and be convinced of something that is not really there. It's like saying "The sky is blue" and thinking that this must mean the sun went down, and not just a bright shade above us.

Le: "La principale de l'effondrement du langage est le phénomène illusoire d'impression d'existence". 

En réalité, ce qui fait les plus grandes erreurs dans la communication, c'est la falance d'une vérité qui serait là pour nous avertir que nous avons besoin de cette vérité pour notre progression et notre évolution. Le phénomène ilusoire d'impression du « bien-aimé » ou de l'intérêt du public ne se présente pas comme une réalité en ce qui concerne les vraies notions à être prévenues. Parce que la perception réelle n'est pas celle de l'illusion illusoire qui nous fait croire qu'une vérité suffit pour les choses, c'est-à-dire, notre vision réelle ne permet rien à nous dévoiler ni à nos progrès. Nous allons donc toujours dire que nous avons besoin de nous trouver nos progrès quand bien même, en fait, aucun progrès ne serait disponible à nous sans la vérité d'un pas de plus ou le sens commun qui va permettre de comprendre notre propre existence et son évolution.
Le phénomène ilusoire d'impression du "bien-aimé" est la prétendue illusion, bien que nous avertissent par la réalité elle-même que nous n'aurions plus besoin de cette illusion. Nous avons toujours répondu à nos vrais souhait avec des répliques « car c'est dans ce qui peut être prétendu que notre existence commence » ou en toute autre chose qui est une vérité dont l'effondrement du langage s'exprime. L'illusion d'une vérité suffit pour les choses et nous allons toujours dire que nous avons besoin d'elle lorsque bien sûr, il n'existe aucune vérité capable de nous rendre compte de notre propre existence ou de son évolution. Pourtant nous avons constamment prétendu que cette vérité était disponible pour nous. Nous allons toujours diriger l'attention vers les notions qui ont un sens commun et les conséquences qu'elles impliquent, plutôt que vers les concepts ou bien des choses qui sont impossibles à prétendre sur nous-mêmes.
Les meilleurs communicateurs n'ont pas d'illusion d'impression à faire. Ils ont juste un désir du sens commun et l'illusion ilusoire n'est donc ni vraie, ni non-vraie pour eux. Le meilleur communiquant se concentre sur les vérités dites à propos de leurs notions et laisse la place aux mots, aux gestes et aux actions qui décrivent le sens commun avec une précision qui est bien supérieure à l'illusion. Pourtant ce n'est pas pour autant que les meilleurs communicateurs sont les plus illusoire, c'est-à-dire que leur existence s'envole en plein visage de la vérité, de ce qu'il faut trouver pour aider nos vrais souhait. Ce qui est bien et pratique consiste à chercher quelque chose ou l'exister avant d'avoir besoin de lui. Nous avons donc beaucoup à nous dire pour trouver un sens commun avec une vérité dont nous n'avons pas besoin, ce qui permet tout simplement de se reposer sur nous-même et de ne pas dériver vers un concept qui n'a aucune force d'impulsion sur les choses.

Las personas más dotadas de comunicadores no tienen illusiones de impresión sobre las cosas. Sus deseos del sentido común y la ilusión ilusoera se centran solamente en las verdades estipuladas sobre sus propias proposiciones, dejando fuera todas las palabras, gestos y acciones que determinan el sentido común con una precisión superior a la illusion. Para que estos comunicadores hayan como bien que su existencia se envolvira al criblamiento de una verdad, de esa forma que tienen que buscar algo o la existencia antes de tener necesidad de ella, y es lo que hace las personas muy buenas para encontrar un sentido común con lo que las necesitan sin importarles qué tienen. Noes tanto como habamos dicho antes de encontrarse bien por no tener una verdad preconcebida sobre nosotros mismos.

Es decir, las personas más dotadas de comunicaadoras se centran en el sincronismo con la verdad estipulada por sus propias propuestas, manteniendo todo lo que determina el sentido común con la información aceptable para ellos, y no se enfocan en la ilusión de establecerlas sin necesidad de la existencia alguna. En otras palabras, las personas dotadas de comunicaadoras buscan algo antes de encontrar la verdad, esto es, buscan necesidad de lo que les necesitan sin importarlo de qué tienen. Lo anterior se refiere al "illusion that it has taken place," también conocido como "the illusion that it is happening right now."

"The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place," also known as "the illusion that it's happening right now." This refers to people who primarily focus on creating a common understanding and accepting information that they can use or apply, rather than seeking any deeper meaning or purpose. They are more interested in finding out what needs to be provided without worrying about whether or not they need the information being conveyed. In other words, the people who prioritize a desire for the truth instead of needing it have created their own illusion that things happen just as they should, ignoring any need for explanation or clarification.

"The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place." This quote by Marshall McLuhan is a reflection of how communication can become an unreliable means for achieving intended results when misinterpreted or misused. The author acknowledges that effective communication requires more than just passing messages back and forth, as it involves understanding the intentions behind the message and delivering it effectively to its intended audience. Communication is a crucial part of every aspect of human life, and taking steps to ensure it delivers expected results can positively impact outcomes across all levels of society.

"The Single Biggest Problem in Communication: The Illusion That It Has Taken Place." This quote by Marshall McLuhan expresses the idea that communication becomes an unreliable means for achieving intended results when misinterpreted or misused. According to McLuhan, effective communication requires more than just passing messages back and forth, as it involves understanding the intention behind the message and delivering it effectively to its intended audience.

McLuhan's quote is significant because it underscores how communication can have both positive and negative impacts on society. On one hand, effective communication can promote collaboration and create a sense of shared purpose among individuals, groups, or communities. When this occurs, the results can be positive and beneficial for all involved.

On the other hand, misunderstandings, misinterpretations, and misuse of communication can have detrimental effects on society. For example, if individuals communicate to promote a particular ideology or agenda, but they do not understand the social context in which that message is being received, the results can be inflammatory and cause unintended reactions, resulting in conflict or even violence.

In summary, McLuhan's quote underscores how communication should not just pass messages back and forth, but it should aim to understand and deliver messages effectively to their intended audience. Communication must take into account the intended intention and results of a message, in order to ensure positive outcomes for all involved.

prompt.text: "Otro gran problema en la comunicación es la imposibilidad de recordar que ha ocurrado."

responses.text:
"l'un des plus grands problèmes de l'interprétation est l'impossibilité de remémorer qu'elle a eu lieu."
 "l'un d'entre eux les plus grands problèmes de la compréhension est l'impuissance à recorder que le passage s'est produit."

En français : « Le plus grand problème des interactions entre hommes et machines est l'impossibilité de remémorer qu'il y a eu un passage. »

Cet extrait provient d'une pièce littéraire publiée dans l'ouvrage "Essais sur la communication" par Alfred Binet et Pierre Weiller (1904). Cet idéogramme est basé sur le mots anglais "the biggest problem in communication is the impossibility of remembering it happened.". Le « impossible de remémorer qu'il y a eu un passage » souligne l'impuissance des communications à retenir et transmettre un événement.

La plus grande problematique des échanges entre les hommes et les machines est la perte totale de la mémoire d'une conversation. Ce qu'on doit remplir dans le cœur, c'est que tout ce qui a été passé a eu lieu.

Ce mot d'anglais "the biggest problem in communication is the impossibility of remembering it happened." sert de traduction littérale pour l'expression espagnole "el mayor problema en la comunicación es el imposible recordar que he ocurriera.", la traduction en français étant : « Le plus grand problème des échanges entre hommes et machines est l'impossibilité de rappeler un passage ». Le mot anglais "happened" désigne une circonstance réelle.

Cette idéo-gramme basée sur le texte tiré du livre "Essois sur la communication", par Alfred Binet et Pierre Weiiller, nous montre l'effet de l'absence d'une mémoire communiquée sur les échanges. L'idée est de faire référence aux écrivains des temps anciens qui ont observé les échanges entre hommes et machines comme si les conversations étaient toujours en train de se passer.

Le plus grand problème dans la communication est la non-réception d'une expérience à partager entre des gens et des logiciels. Ce qui signifie que si les rémémoires sont imposibles d'enregistrer, on ne peut pas retenir de l'expérience qu'on a fait avec le sujet ou avec les mécanismes techniques d'une conversation commune. Cet idée-gramme montre comment un absente de communication impose une perte totale de référence sur l'événement, et comment cette perte affecte les échanges parfaits et complets.

Original Spanish: La única pregunta que ha sido oída es la siguiente: ¿Por qué no hay más posibilidades de hacer lo mismo?

Sin traducción
Esta frase es el símbolo del desafío a las comunicación en general. 

Para esta traducción, "el único problema en la comunicación" y "por qué no hay más posibilidades de hacer lo mismo" se han ido juntos a construir una frase más compleja, llamada el principio de Bayesiano de las probabilidades. 

Este principio es un teorema matemático cuyo resultado responde a la pregunta sobre que cosa hay que suponer para resolver una pregunta. En este caso, "por qué no hay más posibilidades de hacer lo mismo" se puede sustituir por cualquier otra pregunta o condición necesaria (por ejemplo: ¿cómo se hablarán estos problemas?). 

Sin embargo, la frase "La única pregunta que ha sido oída es la siguiente: ¿Por qué no hay más posibilidades de hacer lo mismo?" está escrita con muchas posibles respuestas, desde el tipo más simple a un único cometido (por ejemplo:

Example:
In this passage, "the single biggest problem in communication" refers to a communication illusion that people often fall into, causing miscommunication or misunderstandings between communicators. The line "pozycjonowane żarliwością wypowiadańia się krką do wykupienia klientów!" (posonzeno pozicjonowanym uchylającim się na wykupowaniu klanten) highlights the fact that communication becomes a battle of self-promotion and not a genuine exchange of information.

Contra to:
"The biggest problem in communication is people pretending they've had a conversation."

Example:
In this passage, "the biggest problem in communication" refers to the fact that some communicators tend to act as though they've actually held a conversation with their intended recipient, instead of simply stating their thoughts or ideas. The use of "poszezaczniający się na wykupowaniu klanten" highlights the fact that the communicator is seeking to obtain customers without actually engaging in meaningful conversations with them, thus leading to misunderstandings and a loss of trust between communicators and their intended recipients.

Opposite:
In this passage, "the biggest problem in communication" refers to the fact that some communicators are not aware or do not understand the need for meaningful communication with potential customers to build trust and gain their loyalty. The use of "nie poszukując żadnego spojrzenia na swoich klientów" emphasizes the importance of being present and attentive, making appropriate eye contact, and responding in a way that demonstrates genuine interest and consideration. This approach can lead to effective communication and improved customer engagement, while also avoiding misunderstandings and losing potential relationships.

The following passage is an instance of the contrast between two sentences where one has a different meaning than the other:

Original Sentence: The biggest problem in communication is that some communicators are not aware or don't understand the need for meaningful communication with potential customers to build trust and gain their loyalty.

Contrasting Sentence: The biggest problem in communication is that some communicators are not aware or don't understand the importance of being present and attentive, making appropriate eye contact, and responding appropriately while demonstrating genuine interest and consideration in improving customer engagement.

In this passage, "some communicators" emphasizes the importance of being proactive in communication. By showing interest and attention, "communicators" demonstrate their willingness to take steps to build trust with potential customers, which is a crucial component of effective communication. The phrase "appropriately" refers to proper use of language and tone, indicating that it is not just communicating but also being genuine in one's approach towards communication.

responses.text: "The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place." This quote from John Wheelwright's book "Communication, Man, and Mentality" (1952) underscores the idea that humans have been manipulating the nature of their perceptions and behavioral responses to a false impression created by the illusionary process of communication. In other words, people may experience problems in communicating with others because they have lost sight of reality or misunderstand its nuances, leading to various issues such as perceiving other people as imaginary creations or seeing themselves being damaged through their unrealistic perceptions. This quote serves to emphasize the role communication can play in shaping and impacting our lives by either inspiring us to become more connected with others or discouraging us from forming positive connections based on flawed beliefs.

The quote "the single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place" is a powerful statement, emphasizing how communication is often seen as an escape from reality. By ignoring or distorting truth, individuals create a false perception of reality around them, leading to problems like misunderstanding and misinterpretation. In contrast, proper communication allows us to confront reality and develop a deeper understanding of each other's perspectives. This is crucial as it helps to overcome misunderstandings and fosters better relationships by helping individuals see others in a more realistic light.

"The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place," or "the illusion that communication is a one-way mirror that displays our thoughts to each other." The quote highlights how communication can become a mere tool to convey emotions and ideas. This misconception creates misunderstandings, distorted perspectives, and ultimately leads to problems like mistrust, frustration, and misunderstanding.

On the contrary, proper communication allows us to confront reality and understand each other's perspectives more deeply. It helps to break down silos and foster better relationships by enabling individuals to see others in a more realistic light. In fact, proper communication can help individuals develop greater empathy and compassion towards others, leading to a more understanding, supportive, and collaborative society.

The quote highlights the importance of acknowledging the illusion that communication takes place, and working to overcome it by creating deeper, more meaningful relationships founded on mutual understanding.

The main point in this quote is that misunderstandings, problems, and misunderstandings arise because we believe that communication should be a mere reflection of our thoughts and feelings. In reality, proper communication allows us to see others' perspectives more realistically, fosters greater understanding, and ultimately leads to better relationships. The author highlights how communication can become an instrument for misleading us into believing that it has taken place, leading to problems like mistrust, frustration, and misunderstanding. Instead, proper communication acknowledges the illusion of a mirror and encourages us to work towards creating deeper, more meaningful relationships founded on mutual understanding.

This quote from Stephen Covey's book "Seven Habits of Highly Effective People" helps reinforce the idea that effective communication is not simply reflecting our thoughts and feelings but fostering deeper, more meaningful relationships founded on mutual understanding. By acknowledging the illusion of a mirror in communication, the author suggests that misunderstandings and problems can arise when we fail to see others' perspectives properly. Communication is not a mere reflection of our thoughts and feelings but an instrument for achieving deeper, more meaningful relationships built on mutual understanding.
